content: In the past, we used JSDoc to document our function signatures, using comments to inform code wanderers about the purpose and proper usage of classes, functions, and variables. This isn’t without its problems. Looking at the code, it’s hard to know what a JavaScript promise resolves with. You have to trust that the person who wrote the code documented it correctly and that people who changed it later correctly updated the documentation. In complex systems with countless modules and dependencies, it’s entirely possible to break a function without ever opening the file it lives in.
